content: Visit Northern California in mid-September to mid-October. The higher the elevation, the earlier you’ll be able to see fall leaves. Colors come out in mid-September and peak in late September in the mountains. In the the lower canyons and valleys, you can enjoy the fall foliage until mid-October. [1] Timing may vary from year to year, so check out the California Fall Color Map for real time updates on color changes: /maps/d/viewer?mid=12FSQxbVe9CedswOvJaWaeI5vvYU&ll=37.85374624754116%2C-120.27017115937497&z=6 . Head to Mammoth Lakes and June Lake. Tucked into high canyons on the eastern side of the Sierras, Mammoth Lakes and June Lake are great spots to see some bright fall leaves. Take any road going west off of US 395 near these destinations, and you’ll find yourself smack in the middle of fall splendor. [2] Take a drive through the incredible June Lake Loop, or stroll through Sherwin Creek Campground at Mammoth Lakes to see colorful aspens. Visit Tahoe and Hope Valley. Take a trip to North Lake Tahoe and South Lake Tahoe to see hillsides covered with ruby-gold aspens and willows. Tahoe’s neighbor to the South, Hope Valley, boasts equally striking foliage. [3] In North Lake Tahoe, visit Page Meadows on the lake’s northwest shore to see a brilliant fall display. In South Lake Tahoe, Frederick's Meadow provides a gorgeous view of colorful aspens set against Mount Tallac. In South Lake Tahoe, head to Red Lake, Carson Pass, and Woods Lake for some top-notch views. Take a trip to Yosemite National Park. Visit Yosemite in the fall to see bright yellow cottonwoods, red dogwoods, and golden black oaks and maples. Plus, this national park has majestic granite formations and flowing rivers! [4] Walk around Stoneman's Meadow for a jaw dropping view of Yosemite Valley's east end. Visit Yosemite Chapel on the Valley’s west end to see one of Yosemite’s most famous fall trees: large, bright red sugar maples. Drop by Plumas County in the northern Sierras. Make sure you go to the Lakes Basin Recreation Area for a spectacular view of all the fall foliage. There are waterfalls, alpine lakes, rocky peaks, and miles and miles of trails, so grab your hiking shoes and get ready for an autumn show. Keep in mind that this area is a little lower in elevation than the previous destinations, so its fall colors last until mid-October. [5] Take a drive down Gold Lake Road off of Highway 89. This road offers nearly 20 miles (32.2 km) of fall leaf fun. Visit the town of Quincy for a weekend of fall foliage viewing. Highways 70 and 89 near Quincy are great roads for an autumn driving tour. Go to Nevada City in the Sierra foothills. Spend some time enjoying the bright red sugar maples and American sweetgums lining its streets. These East Coast trees were brought to California by the gold miners of the mid-1800s. Hit up the historic district to see bright fall trees alongside Victorian buildings. Take a detour east of Nevada City to Banner Mountain, where you can take a stroll along the Cascade Canal trail for dazzling views of dogwoods. [6] Stop by Napa Valley to see colorful autumn vineyards. Visit Napa Valley in mid-to late October to see bright trees and radiant fields of grape leaves. If you’re of age, you can do a wine tasting while you take in the scenery. [7] Take a joy ride along Silverado Trail to see Napa Valley fall in all of its glory. Head to the Redwood Trail in Booth Napa Valley State Park to see the big-leaf maples. These guys have leaves larger than your head! Visit Southern California from October to mid-November. Because Southern California is generally lower-elevation than Northern California, the fall foliage here tends to show itself a little later. That’s the beauty of fall foliage in California--it’s around for nearly three months because of the different elevations! [8] Again, timing varies, so it’s a good idea to take a look at the California Fall Color Map to determine the best time to go. Head to Julian in San Diego County. You may know San Diego for its beaches, but turns out the county has some pretty sweet autumn leaves, too. To see them, head to Julian, a historic mining town where fall comes with colorful black oaks, golden ferns, and lots of fresh apples. [9] Take a trip to Lake Cuyamaca in Rancho Cuyamaca State Park, or lace up your hiking boots and take on the Five Oaks Trail at Volcan Mountain Wilderness Preserve. Drive up Palomar mountain to see meadows of deep golden bracken ferns. Travel to Oak Glen for picturesque farms and ranches. Oak Glen, a mile-high town 80 miles (130 km) east of LA, has tons of flaming oak groves and maple trees. Hike through the Wildlands Conservancy’s Oak Glen Preserve and pop by the historic schoolhouse museum for some jaw dropping scenery. [10] Go apple picking at Riley’s Farm, or wander around the corn maze at the historic Rio Rancho, Southern California’s biggest apple farm. Take a trip to Big Bear Lake. Come autumn, you’ll see bright aspens, cottonwoods, and oaks set against a sea of evergreens. Head to Big Bear Village to take a look at the bright red maples. [11] Check out Aspen Grove for one of the best views in the area. Take the Aspen Grove trail, which offers awesome vantage points for fall photographers. Consider taking a hike into San Gorgonio Wilderness. Keep in mind that you’ll need to contact the Mill Creek Ranger station to get a free permit. Try your luck at the Los Angeles County Arboretum. Hidden away in the hills of the San Gabriel Mountains, this gem may have really great fall foliage, depending on the year. Unfortunately, the Santa Ana winds sometimes blow off the leaves before they reach their peak color. [12]

<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California">How to View Fall Foliage in California</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Allyson Edwards</a>
</div>

<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>

Allyson Edwards graduated from Stanford University with a BA in International Relations. Afterwards, she went on to facilitate International partnerships with agencies in over twenty countries, and has consulted for companies in industries across education, fintech, and retail.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">12 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>

<p>You may think California’s all sun, surf, and sand, but it actually boasts some pretty spectacular fall foliage, too. Northern California has tons of spots for dazzling autumn views, and Southern California has a few, too! Plus, California’s varying elevations mean that the window for getting your fall foliage fix is extra long.</p>

</div>
<div data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-channels="6381149051" data-id="scrolltoad" data-maxnonsteps="0" data-maxsteps="2" data-slot="6515934903" data-type="scrollto" id="scrolltoad"></div>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Viewing_Fall_Foliage_in_Northern_California_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Viewing_Fall_Foliage_in_Northern_California">Viewing Fall Foliage in Northern California</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1257052" href="#/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b9/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_b3128fe82f" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b3128fe82f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b9/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Visit Northern California in mid-September to mid-October.</b> The higher the elevation, the earlier you’ll be able to see fall leaves. Colors come out in mid-September and peak in late September in the mountains. In the the lower canyons and valleys, you can enjoy the fall foliage until mid-October.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Timing may vary from year to year, so check out the California Fall Color Map for real time updates on color changes: <a class="external free" href="https://www.google.com/maps/d/viewer?mid=12FSQxbVe9CedswOvJaWaeI5vvYU&ll=37.85374624754116%2C-120.27017115937497&z=6" rel="nofollow">https://www.google.com/maps/d/viewer?mid=12FSQxbVe9CedswOvJaWaeI5vvYU&ll=37.85374624754116%2C-120.27017115937497&z=6</a>.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-2-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1257052" href="#/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-2-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_04d741ee2d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_04d741ee2d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Head to Mammoth Lakes and June Lake.</b> Tucked into high canyons on the eastern side of the Sierras, Mammoth Lakes and June Lake are great spots to see some bright fall leaves. Take any road going west off of US 395 near these destinations, and you’ll find yourself smack in the middle of fall splendor.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Take a drive through the incredible June Lake Loop, or stroll through Sherwin Creek Campground at Mammoth Lakes to see colorful aspens.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-3-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1257052" href="#/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-3-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_3daaa364ac" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3daaa364ac')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Visit Tahoe and Hope Valley.</b> Take a trip to North Lake Tahoe and South Lake Tahoe to see hillsides covered with ruby-gold aspens and willows. Tahoe’s neighbor to the South, Hope Valley, boasts equally striking foliage.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>In North Lake Tahoe, visit Page Meadows on the lake’s northwest shore to see a brilliant fall display. In South Lake Tahoe, Frederick's Meadow provides a gorgeous view of colorful aspens set against Mount Tallac.</li>
<li>In South Lake Tahoe, head to Red Lake, Carson Pass, and Woods Lake for some top-notch views.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-4-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1257052" href="#/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-4-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_c079573c39" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c079573c39')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Take a trip to Yosemite National Park.</b> Visit Yosemite in the fall to see bright yellow cottonwoods, red dogwoods, and golden black oaks and maples. Plus, this national park has majestic granite formations and flowing rivers!<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Walk around Stoneman's Meadow for a jaw dropping view of Yosemite Valley's east end.</li>
<li>Visit Yosemite Chapel on the Valley’s west end to see one of Yosemite’s most famous fall trees: large, bright red sugar maples.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-5-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1257052" href="#/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-5-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e5/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_91e531c6fd" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_91e531c6fd')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e5/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Drop by Plumas County in the northern Sierras.</b> Make sure you go to the Lakes Basin Recreation Area for a spectacular view of all the fall foliage. There are waterfalls, alpine lakes, rocky peaks, and miles and miles of trails, so grab your hiking shoes and get ready for an autumn show. Keep in mind that this area is a little lower in elevation than the previous destinations, so its fall colors last until mid-October.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Take a drive down Gold Lake Road off of Highway 89. This road offers nearly 20 miles (32.2 km) of fall leaf fun.</li>
<li>Visit the town of Quincy for a weekend of fall foliage viewing. Highways 70 and 89 near Quincy are great roads for an autumn driving tour.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-6-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1257052" href="#/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-6-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/29/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_ea62d28858" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ea62d28858')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/29/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Go to Nevada City in the Sierra foothills.</b> Spend some time enjoying the bright red sugar maples and American sweetgums lining its streets. These East Coast trees were brought to California by the gold miners of the mid-1800s.

<ul>
<li>Hit up the historic district to see bright fall trees alongside Victorian buildings.</li>
<li>Take a detour east of Nevada City to Banner Mountain, where you can take a stroll along the Cascade Canal trail for dazzling views of dogwoods.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-7-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1257052" href="#/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-7-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3e/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_f9920c111d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f9920c111d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3e/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Stop by Napa Valley to see colorful autumn vineyards.</b> Visit Napa Valley in mid-to late October to see bright trees and radiant fields of grape leaves. If you’re of age, you can do a wine tasting while you take in the scenery.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Take a joy ride along Silverado Trail to see Napa Valley fall in all of its glory.</li>
<li>Head to the Redwood Trail in Booth Napa Valley State Park to see the big-leaf maples. These guys have leaves larger than your head!</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">

</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Viewing_Fall_Foliage_in_Southern_California_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Viewing_Fall_Foliage_in_Southern_California">Viewing Fall Foliage in Southern California</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-8-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1257052" href="#/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-8-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-8-Version-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_a7c7a47506" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a7c7a47506')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-8-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Visit Southern California from October to mid-November.</b> Because Southern California is generally lower-elevation than Northern California, the fall foliage here tends to show itself a little later. That’s the beauty of fall foliage in California--it’s around for nearly three months because of the different elevations!<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Again, timing varies, so it’s a good idea to take a look at the California Fall Color Map to determine the best time to go.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-9-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1257052" href="#/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-9-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d8/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_3f8d61bf0e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3f8d61bf0e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d8/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Head to Julian in San Diego County.</b> You may know San Diego for its beaches, but turns out the county has some pretty sweet autumn leaves, too. To see them, head to Julian, a historic mining town where fall comes with colorful black oaks, golden ferns, and lots of fresh apples.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Take a trip to Lake Cuyamaca in Rancho Cuyamaca State Park, or lace up your hiking boots and take on the Five Oaks Trail at Volcan Mountain Wilderness Preserve.</li>
<li>Drive up Palomar mountain to see meadows of deep golden bracken ferns.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-10-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1257052" href="#/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-10-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" height="485" id="img_8c85052ab6" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_8c85052ab6')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Travel to Oak Glen for picturesque farms and ranches.</b> Oak Glen, a mile-high town 80 miles (130 km) east of LA, has tons of flaming oak groves and maple trees. Hike through the Wildlands Conservancy’s Oak Glen Preserve and pop by the historic schoolhouse museum for some jaw dropping scenery.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Go apple picking at Riley’s Farm, or wander around the corn maze at the historic Rio Rancho, Southern California’s biggest apple farm.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1257052" href="#/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-11.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-11.jpg" height="485" id="img_2ed43cdc35" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2ed43cdc35')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="485" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-11.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Take a trip to Big Bear Lake.</b> Come autumn, you’ll see bright aspens, cottonwoods, and oaks set against a sea of evergreens. Head to Big Bear Village to take a look at the bright red maples.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Check out Aspen Grove for one of the best views in the area. Take the Aspen Grove trail, which offers awesome vantage points for fall photographers.</li>
<li>Consider taking a hike into San Gorgonio Wilderness. Keep in mind that you’ll need to contact the Mill Creek Ranger station to get a free permit.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1257052" href="#/Image:View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled View Fall Foliage in California Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-12.jpg/aid1257052-v4-728px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-12.jpg" height="485" id="img_e4e63b5727" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e4e63b5727')</script>
</div>

<b class="whb">Try your luck at the Los Angeles County Arboretum.</b> Hidden away in the hills of the San Gabriel Mountains, this gem may have really great fall foliage, depending on the year. <div class="qa_answer answer">Many trees in Northern California are evergreens, which look regal regardless of the time of year, but there are fewer trees in California that will turn the vivid, fiery colors of New England's autumn.</div>

        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/67\/View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-12.jpg\/aid1257052-v4-1200px-View-Fall-Foliage-in-California-Step-12.jpg",
        "width": 1200,
        "height": 800
    },
    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",

        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",

            "width": 326,
            "height": 60

        "sameAs": [

            "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"

    "aggregateRating": {
        "@type": "AggregateRating",
        "bestRating": 100,

        "ratingValue": 100
    },
    "datePublished": "2011-02-18",
    "dateModified": "2019-03-29",
    "publisher": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",

            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"

    "contributor": {
        "@type": "Person",
        "name": "Allyson Edwards"
    },
    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Viewing Fall Foliage in Northern California",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Visit Northern California in mid-September to mid-October. The higher the elevation, the earlier you\u2019ll be able to see fall leaves. Colors come out in mid-September and peak in late September in the mountains. In the the lower canyons and valleys, you can enjoy the fall foliage until mid-October.[1]\nTiming may vary from year to year, so check out the California Fall Color Map for real time updates on color changes: https:\/\/www.google.com\/maps\/d\/viewer?mid=12FSQxbVe9CedswOvJaWaeI5vvYU&ll=37.85374624754116%2C-120.27017115937497&z=6."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Head to Mammoth Lakes and June Lake. Tucked into high canyons on the eastern side of the Sierras, Mammoth Lakes and June Lake are great spots to see some bright fall leaves. Take any road going west off of US 395 near these destinations, and you\u2019ll find yourself smack in the middle of fall splendor.[2]\nTake a drive through the incredible June Lake Loop, or stroll through Sherwin Creek Campground at Mammoth Lakes to see colorful aspens."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Visit Tahoe and Hope Valley. Take a trip to North Lake Tahoe and South Lake Tahoe to see hillsides covered with ruby-gold aspens and willows. Tahoe\u2019s neighbor to the South, Hope Valley, boasts equally striking foliage.[3]\nIn North Lake Tahoe, visit Page Meadows on the lake\u2019s northwest shore to see a brilliant fall display. In South Lake Tahoe, Frederick's Meadow provides a gorgeous view of colorful aspens set against Mount Tallac.\nIn South Lake Tahoe, head to Red Lake, Carson Pass, and Woods Lake for some top-notch views."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Take a trip to Yosemite National Park. Visit Yosemite in the fall to see bright yellow cottonwoods, red dogwoods, and golden black oaks and maples. Plus, this national park has majestic granite formations and flowing rivers![4]\nWalk around Stoneman's Meadow for a jaw dropping view of Yosemite Valley's east end.\nVisit Yosemite Chapel on the Valley\u2019s west end to see one of Yosemite\u2019s most famous fall trees: large, bright red sugar maples."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Drop by Plumas County in the northern Sierras. Make sure you go to the Lakes Basin Recreation Area for a spectacular view of all the fall foliage. There are waterfalls, alpine lakes, rocky peaks, and miles and miles of trails, so grab your hiking shoes and get ready for an autumn show. Keep in mind that this area is a little lower in elevation than the previous destinations, so its fall colors last until mid-October.[5]\nTake a drive down Gold Lake Road off of Highway 89. This road offers nearly 20 miles (32.2\u00a0km) of fall leaf fun.\nVisit the town of Quincy for a weekend of fall foliage viewing. Highways 70 and 89 near Quincy are great roads for an autumn driving tour."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 6,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Go to Nevada City in the Sierra foothills. Spend some time enjoying the bright red sugar maples and American sweetgums lining its streets. These East Coast trees were brought to California by the gold miners of the mid-1800s.\n\nHit up the historic district to see bright fall trees alongside Victorian buildings.\nTake a detour east of Nevada City to Banner Mountain, where you can take a stroll along the Cascade Canal trail for dazzling views of dogwoods.[6]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 7,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Stop by Napa Valley to see colorful autumn vineyards. Visit Napa Valley in mid-to late October to see bright trees and radiant fields of grape leaves. If you\u2019re of age, you can do a wine tasting while you take in the scenery.[7]\nTake a joy ride along Silverado Trail to see Napa Valley fall in all of its glory.\nHead to the Redwood Trail in Booth Napa Valley State Park to see the big-leaf maples. These guys have leaves larger than your head!"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Viewing Fall Foliage in Southern California",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Visit Southern California from October to mid-November. Because Southern California is generally lower-elevation than Northern California, the fall foliage here tends to show itself a little later. That\u2019s the beauty of fall foliage in California--it\u2019s around for nearly three months because of the different elevations![8]\nAgain, timing varies, so it\u2019s a good idea to take a look at the California Fall Color Map to determine the best time to go."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Head to Julian in San Diego County. You may know San Diego for its beaches, but turns out the county has some pretty sweet autumn leaves, too. To see them, head to Julian, a historic mining town where fall comes with colorful black oaks, golden ferns, and lots of fresh apples.[9]\nTake a trip to Lake Cuyamaca in Rancho Cuyamaca State Park, or lace up your hiking boots and take on the Five Oaks Trail at Volcan Mountain Wilderness Preserve.\nDrive up Palomar mountain to see meadows of deep golden bracken ferns."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Travel to Oak Glen for picturesque farms and ranches. Oak Glen, a mile-high town 80 miles (130\u00a0km) east of LA, has tons of flaming oak groves and maple trees. Hike through the Wildlands Conservancy\u2019s Oak Glen Preserve and pop by the historic schoolhouse museum for some jaw dropping scenery.[10]\nGo apple picking at Riley\u2019s Farm, or wander around the corn maze at the historic Rio Rancho, Southern California\u2019s biggest apple farm."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Take a trip to Big Bear Lake. Come autumn, you\u2019ll see bright aspens, cottonwoods, and oaks set against a sea of evergreens. Head to Big Bear Village to take a look at the bright red maples.[11]\nCheck out Aspen Grove for one of the best views in the area. Take the Aspen Grove trail, which offers awesome vantage points for fall photographers.\nConsider taking a hike into San Gorgonio Wilderness. Keep in mind that you\u2019ll need to contact the Mill Creek Ranger station to get a free permit."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Try your luck at the Los Angeles County Arboretum. Hidden away in the hills of the San Gabriel Mountains, this gem may have really great fall foliage, depending on the year. Unfortunately, the Santa Ana winds sometimes blow off the leaves before they reach their peak color.[12]"
                    }
                }
            ]
        }
    ],
    "description": "How to View Fall Foliage in California. You may think California's all sun, surf, and sand, but it actually boasts some pretty spectacular fall foliage, too. Northern California has tons of spots for dazzling autumn views, and Southern..."
}</script>

title: How to View Fall Foliage in California
content_html:
Visit Northern California in mid-September to mid-October. The higher the elevation, the earlier you’ll be able to see fall leaves. Colors come out in mid-September and peak in late September in the mountains. In the the lower canyons and valleys, you can enjoy the fall foliage until mid-October.[1]
  • Timing may vary from year to year, so check out the California Fall Color Map for real time updates on color changes: https://www.google.com/maps/d/viewer?mid=12FSQxbVe9CedswOvJaWaeI5vvYU&ll=37.85374624754116%2C-120.27017115937497&z=6.
Head to Mammoth Lakes and June Lake. Tucked into high canyons on the eastern side of the Sierras, Mammoth Lakes and June Lake are great spots to see some bright fall leaves. Take any road going west off of US 395 near these destinations, and you’ll find yourself smack in the middle of fall splendor.[2]
  • Take a drive through the incredible June Lake Loop, or stroll through Sherwin Creek Campground at Mammoth Lakes to see colorful aspens.
Visit Tahoe and Hope Valley. Take a trip to North Lake Tahoe and South Lake Tahoe to see hillsides covered with ruby-gold aspens and willows. Tahoe’s neighbor to the South, Hope Valley, boasts equally striking foliage.[3]
  • In North Lake Tahoe, visit Page Meadows on the lake’s northwest shore to see a brilliant fall display. In South Lake Tahoe, Frederick's Meadow provides a gorgeous view of colorful aspens set against Mount Tallac.
  • In South Lake Tahoe, head to Red Lake, Carson Pass, and Woods Lake for some top-notch views.
Take a trip to Yosemite National Park. Visit Yosemite in the fall to see bright yellow cottonwoods, red dogwoods, and golden black oaks and maples. Plus, this national park has majestic granite formations and flowing rivers![4]
  • Walk around Stoneman's Meadow for a jaw dropping view of Yosemite Valley's east end.
  • Visit Yosemite Chapel on the Valley’s west end to see one of Yosemite’s most famous fall trees: large, bright red sugar maples.
Drop by Plumas County in the northern Sierras. Make sure you go to the Lakes Basin Recreation Area for a spectacular view of all the fall foliage. There are waterfalls, alpine lakes, rocky peaks, and miles and miles of trails, so grab your hiking shoes and get ready for an autumn show. Keep in mind that this area is a little lower in elevation than the previous destinations, so its fall colors last until mid-October.[5]
  • Take a drive down Gold Lake Road off of Highway 89. This road offers nearly 20 miles (32.2 km) of fall leaf fun.
  • Visit the town of Quincy for a weekend of fall foliage viewing. Highways 70 and 89 near Quincy are great roads for an autumn driving tour.
Go to Nevada City in the Sierra foothills. Spend some time enjoying the bright red sugar maples and American sweetgums lining its streets. These East Coast trees were brought to California by the gold miners of the mid-1800s.
  • Hit up the historic district to see bright fall trees alongside Victorian buildings.
  • Take a detour east of Nevada City to Banner Mountain, where you can take a stroll along the Cascade Canal trail for dazzling views of dogwoods.[6]
Stop by Napa Valley to see colorful autumn vineyards. Visit Napa Valley in mid-to late October to see bright trees and radiant fields of grape leaves. If you’re of age, you can do a wine tasting while you take in the scenery.[7]
  • Take a joy ride along Silverado Trail to see Napa Valley fall in all of its glory.
  • Head to the Redwood Trail in Booth Napa Valley State Park to see the big-leaf maples. These guys have leaves larger than your head!
Visit Southern California from October to mid-November. Because Southern California is generally lower-elevation than Northern California, the fall foliage here tends to show itself a little later. That’s the beauty of fall foliage in California--it’s around for nearly three months because of the different elevations![8]
  • Again, timing varies, so it’s a good idea to take a look at the California Fall Color Map to determine the best time to go.
Head to Julian in San Diego County. You may know San Diego for its beaches, but turns out the county has some pretty sweet autumn leaves, too. To see them, head to Julian, a historic mining town where fall comes with colorful black oaks, golden ferns, and lots of fresh apples.[9]
  • Take a trip to Lake Cuyamaca in Rancho Cuyamaca State Park, or lace up your hiking boots and take on the Five Oaks Trail at Volcan Mountain Wilderness Preserve.
  • Drive up Palomar mountain to see meadows of deep golden bracken ferns.
Travel to Oak Glen for picturesque farms and ranches. Oak Glen, a mile-high town 80 miles (130 km) east of LA, has tons of flaming oak groves and maple trees. Hike through the Wildlands Conservancy’s Oak Glen Preserve and pop by the historic schoolhouse museum for some jaw dropping scenery.[10]
  • Go apple picking at Riley’s Farm, or wander around the corn maze at the historic Rio Rancho, Southern California’s biggest apple farm.
Take a trip to Big Bear Lake. Come autumn, you’ll see bright aspens, cottonwoods, and oaks set against a sea of evergreens. Head to Big Bear Village to take a look at the bright red maples.[11]
  • Check out Aspen Grove for one of the best views in the area. Take the Aspen Grove trail, which offers awesome vantage points for fall photographers.
  • Consider taking a hike into San Gorgonio Wilderness. Keep in mind that you’ll need to contact the Mill Creek Ranger station to get a free permit.
Try your luck at the Los Angeles County Arboretum. Hidden away in the hills of the San Gabriel Mountains, this gem may have really great fall foliage, depending on the year. Unfortunately, the Santa Ana winds sometimes blow off the leaves before they reach their peak color.[12]
